caption: Palmyra Atoll is an unoccupied equatorial Northern Pacific atoll of some 12 sq km (4.6 sq mi) administered by the US Government. It is located almost due south of the Hawaiian Islands, roughly halfway between Hawaii and American Samoa. The atoll consists of an extensive reef, two shallow lagoons, and some 50 sand and reef-rock islets and bars covered with vegetation. Photo courtesy of NASA/USGS.

full.altText: Palmyra Atoll is an unoccupied equatorial Northern Pacific atoll of some 12 sq km (4.6 sq mi) administered by the US Government. It is located almost due south of the Hawaiian Islands, roughly halfway between Hawaii and American Samoa. The atoll consists of an extensive reef, two shallow lagoons, and some 50 sand and reef-rock islets and bars covered with vegetation. Photo courtesy of NASA/USGS.

thumb.altText: Palmyra Atoll is an unoccupied equatorial Northern Pacific atoll of some 12 sq km (4.6 sq mi) administered by the US Government. It is located almost due south of the Hawaiian Islands, roughly halfway between Hawaii and American Samoa. The atoll consists of an extensive reef, two shallow lagoons, and some 50 sand and reef-rock islets and bars covered with vegetation. Photo courtesy of NASA/USGS.

caption: Palmyra Atoll is an unoccupied equatorial Northern Pacific atoll of some 12 sq km (4.6 sq mi) administered by the US Government. It is located almost due south of the Hawaiian Islands, roughly halfway between Hawaii and American Samoa. The atoll consists of an extensive reef, two shallow lagoons, and some 50 sand and reef-rock islets and bars covered with vegetation. The variable temporary population of 4 to 20 "non-occupants" consists of staff and scientists employed by various departments of the US Government and The Nature Conservancy, as well as a rotating mix of Palmyra Atoll Research Consortium scholars pursuing research. Photo courtesy of NASA.

full.altText: Palmyra Atoll is an unoccupied equatorial Northern Pacific atoll of some 12 sq km (4.6 sq mi) administered by the US Government. It is located almost due south of the Hawaiian Islands, roughly halfway between Hawaii and American Samoa. The atoll consists of an extensive reef, two shallow lagoons, and some 50 sand and reef-rock islets and bars covered with vegetation. The variable temporary population of 4 to 20 "non-occupants" consists of staff and scientists employed by various departments of the US Government and The Nature Conservancy, as well as a rotating mix of Palmyra Atoll Research Consortium scholars pursuing research. Photo courtesy of NASA.

thumb.altText: Palmyra Atoll is an unoccupied equatorial Northern Pacific atoll of some 12 sq km (4.6 sq mi) administered by the US Government. It is located almost due south of the Hawaiian Islands, roughly halfway between Hawaii and American Samoa. The atoll consists of an extensive reef, two shallow lagoons, and some 50 sand and reef-rock islets and bars covered with vegetation. The variable temporary population of 4 to 20 "non-occupants" consists of staff and scientists employed by various departments of the US Government and The Nature Conservancy, as well as a rotating mix of Palmyra Atoll Research Consortium scholars pursuing research. Photo courtesy of NASA.

caption: Remnant of the historic Battle of Midway, this anti-aircraft gun at Eastern Island in Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge is surrounded by nesting albatross. On 13 September 2000, the Secretary of the Interior designated the lands and waters of Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge as the Battle of Midway National Memorial, “so that the heroic courage and sacrifice of those who fought against overwhelming odds to win an incredible victory will never be forgotten.” This is the first National Memorial to be designated on a National Wildlife Refuge. Photo courtesy of USFWS/David Patte.

full.altText: Remnant of the historic Battle of Midway, this anti-aircraft gun at Eastern Island in Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge is surrounded by nesting albatross. On 13 September 2000, the Secretary of the Interior designated the lands and waters of Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge as the Battle of Midway National Memorial, “so that the heroic courage and sacrifice of those who fought against overwhelming odds to win an incredible victory will never be forgotten.” This is the first National Memorial to be designated on a National Wildlife Refuge. Photo courtesy of USFWS/David Patte.

thumb.altText: Remnant of the historic Battle of Midway, this anti-aircraft gun at Eastern Island in Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge is surrounded by nesting albatross. On 13 September 2000, the Secretary of the Interior designated the lands and waters of Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge as the Battle of Midway National Memorial, “so that the heroic courage and sacrifice of those who fought against overwhelming odds to win an incredible victory will never be forgotten.” This is the first National Memorial to be designated on a National Wildlife Refuge. Photo courtesy of USFWS/David Patte.

caption: The Battle of Midway National Monument sits at the Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge. The Battle of Midway, fought over and near the Midway Atoll, approximately 2,800 km (1,500 nautical mi) northwest of Hawaii, represents a turning point in the Pacific Theater of World War II. Photo courtesy of the US Navy/ Mass Communication Specialist 2nd Class Daniel Barker.

full.altText: The Battle of Midway National Monument sits at the Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge. The Battle of Midway, fought over and near the Midway Atoll, approximately 2,800 km (1,500 nautical mi) northwest of Hawaii, represents a turning point in the Pacific Theater of World War II. Photo courtesy of the US Navy/ Mass Communication Specialist 2nd Class Daniel Barker.

thumb.altText: The Battle of Midway National Monument sits at the Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge. The Battle of Midway, fought over and near the Midway Atoll, approximately 2,800 km (1,500 nautical mi) northwest of Hawaii, represents a turning point in the Pacific Theater of World War II. Photo courtesy of the US Navy/ Mass Communication Specialist 2nd Class Daniel Barker.

caption: The American Battle Monuments Commission authorized the creation of a Midway Memorial Marker in May 2013 to commemorate the 4–7 June 1942 Battle of Midway. On 12 August 2015, the Midway Memorial Marker was officially erected on the island. Image courtesy USFWS/ Megan Nagel.

full.altText: The American Battle Monuments Commission authorized the creation of a Midway Memorial Marker in May 2013 to commemorate the 4–7 June 1942 Battle of Midway. On 12 August 2015, the Midway Memorial Marker was officially erected on the island. Image courtesy USFWS/ Megan Nagel.

caption: Midway Atoll is a 6.2 sq km (2.4 sq mi) atoll in the North Pacific Ocean. As its name suggests, Midway is roughly equidistant between North America and Asia, and lies almost halfway around the world from Greenwich, England. It is near the northwestern end of the Hawaiian archipelago, about one-third of the way from Honolulu, Hawaii to Tokyo, Japan. Photo courtesy of NASA.

full.altText: Midway Atoll is a 6.2 sq km (2.4 sq mi) atoll in the North Pacific Ocean. As its name suggests, Midway is roughly equidistant between North America and Asia, and lies almost halfway around the world from Greenwich, England. It is near the northwestern end of the Hawaiian archipelago, about one-third of the way from Honolulu, Hawaii to Tokyo, Japan. Photo courtesy of NASA.

thumb.altText: Midway Atoll is a 6.2 sq km (2.4 sq mi) atoll in the North Pacific Ocean. As its name suggests, Midway is roughly equidistant between North America and Asia, and lies almost halfway around the world from Greenwich, England. It is near the northwestern end of the Hawaiian archipelago, about one-third of the way from Honolulu, Hawaii to Tokyo, Japan. Photo courtesy of NASA.

caption: Wreckage scattered and pushed around the reef flat and rubble spit at Kingman Reef National Wildlife Refuge causes considerable damage and must be periodically removed. Image courtesy USFWS.

full.altText: Wreckage scattered and pushed around the reef flat and rubble spit at Kingman Reef National Wildlife Refuge causes considerable damage and must be periodically removed. Image courtesy USFWS.

thumb.altText: Wreckage scattered and pushed around the reef flat and rubble spit at Kingman Reef National Wildlife Refuge causes considerable damage and must be periodically removed. Image courtesy USFWS.

caption: There are only a few small spits of coral and shell rubble that break the surface at Kingman Reef National Wildlife Refuge. This bow of a shipwreck - along with much additional submerged material - was removed in January 2014. Wreck debris buffeted by waves can cause a great deal of damage to coral. Image courtesy of the USFWS.

full.altText: There are only a few small spits of coral and shell rubble that break the surface at Kingman Reef National Wildlife Refuge. This bow of a shipwreck - along with much additional submerged material - was removed in January 2014. Wreck debris buffeted by waves can cause a great deal of damage to coral. Image courtesy of the USFWS.

thumb.altText: There are only a few small spits of coral and shell rubble that break the surface at Kingman Reef National Wildlife Refuge. This bow of a shipwreck - along with much additional submerged material - was removed in January 2014. Wreck debris buffeted by waves can cause a great deal of damage to coral. Image courtesy of the USFWS.

caption: Aerial view of the exposed portion of Kingman Reef. Photo courtesy of the USFWS/Susan White.

full.altText: Aerial view of the exposed portion of Kingman Reef. Photo courtesy of the USFWS/Susan White.

thumb.altText: Aerial view of the exposed portion of Kingman Reef. Photo courtesy of the USFWS/Susan White.

caption: Landsat photo gives clear view of the entire triangular shape of Kingman Reef and distinctly shows the roughly two-thirds that is submerged and one-third that is exposed. Image courtesy of NASA.

full.altText: Landsat photo gives clear view of the entire triangular shape of Kingman Reef and distinctly shows the roughly two-thirds that is submerged and one-third that is exposed. Image courtesy of NASA.

thumb.altText: Landsat photo gives clear view of the entire triangular shape of Kingman Reef and distinctly shows the roughly two-thirds that is submerged and one-third that is exposed. Image courtesy of NASA.

caption: Astronaut photo of Kingman Reef, a largely submerged, uninhabited triangular structure in the North Pacific Ocean, roughly halfway between the Hawaiian Islands and American Samoa. The reef lagoon is 82 m (270 ft) deep at the western part and the total enclosed area is about 76 sq km (29 sq mi). The east-west and northwest-southeast trending small strips of dry land (gray color) are composed of coral rubble and giant clamshells. The highest point on the reef is less than 1.5 m (5 ft) above sea level, which is awash most of the time, making Kingman Reef a maritime hazard. Image courtesy of NASA.

full.altText: Astronaut photo of Kingman Reef, a largely submerged, uninhabited triangular structure in the North Pacific Ocean, roughly halfway between the Hawaiian Islands and American Samoa. The east-west and northwest-southeast trending small strips of dry land (gray color) are composed of coral rubble and giant clamshells. The highest point on the reef is less than 1.5 m (5 ft) above sea level, which is awash most of the time, making Kingman Reef a maritime hazard. Image courtesy of NASA.

caption: The white tern is famous for laying its egg on a rock, a rock ledge, or a bare branch rather than in a nest. An egg laid in an exposed and precarious place results in a chick that must cling to the perch. Image courtesy USFWS.

caption: Satellite photo of Johnston Atoll, about 1,390 km (860 mi) west of Hawaii. Four islands compose the total land mass of 2.6 sq km. Johnston and Sand islands are both enlarged natural features, while Akau and Hikina are two artificial islands formed by coral dredging. Johnston Island, by far the largest, somewhat resembles the flattop of an aircraft carrier and contains an airstrip. Photo courtesy of NASA.

full.altText: Satellite photo of Johnston Atoll, about 1,390 km (860 mi) west of Hawaii. Four islands compose the total land mass of 2.6 sq km. Johnston and Sand islands are both enlarged natural features, while Akau and Hikina are two artificial islands formed by coral dredging. Johnston Island, by far the largest, somewhat resembles the flattop of an aircraft carrier and contains an airstrip. Photo courtesy of NASA.

caption: Montipora genus corals are most common in shallow reef environments with bright sunlight and moderate wave motion. Small reef fishes, such as the hawkfish, live near Montipora colonies and perch on the ridges of the coral. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

full.altText: Montipora genus corals are most common in shallow reef environments with bright sunlight and moderate wave motion. Small reef fishes, such as the hawkfish, live near Montipora colonies and perch on the ridges of the coral. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

caption: The Bristle-thighed curlew is a medium-sized shorebird that breeds in Alaska and winters on tropical Pacific islands. It has a dark brown eye stripe; a long, down-curved bill; and long, grayish-blue legs. It has a barred tail, a mottled brown back, a reddish-brown belly and rump, a streaked brown breast, and a light brown head and neck. It gets its name from the bristly feathers at the ends of its thighs and it feeds on crustaceans, small fish, bird eggs, and snails. Here a pair of curlews conduct an inspection tour on a Jarvis Island beach. Image courtesy of the USFWS.

full.altText: The Bristle-thighed curlew is a medium-sized shorebird that breeds in Alaska and winters on tropical Pacific islands. Here a pair of curlews conduct an inspection tour on a Jarvis Island beach. Image courtesy of the USFWS.

caption: A small, delicate tern, the blue noddy is distinctive due to its pale plumage, with an all-grey head and upperparts and even paler white-grey underparts. The upper wing is slightly darker than the rest of the body. Here a noddy sails in for a landing on Jarvis Island. Photo courtesy of the USFWS.

caption: The ruddy turnstone is a dramatically colored shorebird with short orange legs, variegated russet color pattern on its back, and black and white head, throat, neck and breast. Here a group of turnstones gathers along a Jarvis Island shoreline. Image courtesy of the USFWS.

caption: Remains of a guano tramway on Jarvis Island, looking west with late-19th century heaps of mined but never-shipped guano in the background near the day beacon. Image courtesy of USFWS.

caption: Jarvis Island is an uninhabited 4.5 sq km (1.75 sq mi) coral island located in the South Pacific Ocean. Unlike most coral atolls, the central lagoon on Jarvis is wholly dry; its deep guano deposits were mined for about 20 years during the 19th century. Image courtesy of NASA.

full.altText: Jarvis Island is an uninhabited 4.5 sq km (1.75 sq mi) coral island located in the South Pacific Ocean. Unlike most coral atolls, the central lagoon on Jarvis is wholly dry; its deep guano deposits were mined for about 20 years during the 19th century. Image courtesy of NASA.

caption: Jarvis Island is an uninhabited 4.5 sq km (1.75 sq mi) coral island located in the South Pacific Ocean. Unlike most coral atolls, the central lagoon on Jarvis is wholly dry. Note the submerged reef beyond the eastern shore of the island (top). Image courtesy of NASA.

caption: Bristle-thighed curlews are shorebirds that breed on inland tundra in a small area of western Alaska and winter on small tropical islands across a large expanse of the Pacific Ocean - including on Howland Island. Image courtesy of the USFWS.

caption: Wandering tattlers are slate-gray in color with greenish-yellow legs. They are easily recognized because they stand near water and bob their tails up and down. The long black bill is distinctive, nosing in the sand for food. Image courtesy of the USFWS.

caption: A great frigatebird mother and chick on Howland Island. These birds have a distinctive scissor-shaped tail and greatly elongated angular wings, allowing them to make spectacular flight maneuvers and soar almost effortlessly above the ocean. Photo courtesy of the USFWS.

caption: Sign on Howland Island proclaiming its status as a wildlife refuge. The "Earhart Light" day beacon (an unlighted nautical sea mark) is on the right. Photo courtesy USFWS/C. Newton

caption: Howland Island is an uninhabited coral island located just north of the equator in the central Pacific Ocean, about 3,100 km southwest of Honolulu - almost halfway between Hawaii and Australia. The island is composed of coral fragments and is surrounded by an active fringing reef. White breakers encircling the island indicate the position of the reef. Image courtesy of NASA.

caption: Large numbers of hermit crabs are found on Baker Island; they like to congregate in the shade of the old lighthouse. Photo courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

caption: Two hermit crabs on Baker Island. The crabs have soft exoskeletons and rely on the scavenged abandoned shells of marine snails for their protection. There are over 800 species of hermit crab, all of which must occupy shelter produced by other organism or risk being defenseless. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

thumb.altText: Two masked boobies patrol the shoreline on Baker Island National Wildlife Refuge in the Pacific Ocean 2,600 km (1,600 mi) southwest of Honolulu. Image courtesy of USFWS.

caption: The masked booby is the largest of the booby family. Adults are a little under a meter in length and their wingspan is about 1.5 meters. Photo courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

full.altText: The masked booby is the largest of the booby family. Adults are a little under a meter in length and their wingspan is about 1.5 meters. Photo courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

caption: Blue noddies typically remain near their breeding colonies year-round, and are rarely found far from land. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

full.altText: Blue noddies typically remain near their breeding colonies year-round, and are rarely found far from land. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

thumb.altText: Blue noddies typically remain near their breeding colonies year-round, and are rarely found far from land. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

caption: Resting frigatebird on Baker Island. Image courtesy of the US Fish and and Wildlife Service.

full.altText: Resting frigatebird on Baker Island. Image courtesy of the US Fish and and Wildlife Service.

thumb.altText: Resting frigatebird on Baker Island. Image courtesy of the US Fish and and Wildlife Service.

caption: American settlers arrived on Baker Island in 1935 and built a lighthouse; the settlement was evacuated at the start of World War II and the island has been uninhabited and very rarely visited since then. The lighthouse tower still stands; it is now charted as a day beacon (an unlighted nautical sea mark). Image courtesy of the US Fish and and Wildlife Service.

caption: Baker Island as seen from the international space station orbiting at a height of about 350 km. Photo courtesy of NASA.
